doc.field: New York University Archives Collection of the Washington Square College Bulletin
New York University Archives Collection of the Washington Square College Bulletin

This collection contains issues from the student newspaper the Washington Square College Bulletin dating from 1933 to 1955. This newspaper documented student life at NYU's Washington Square campus, athletics, local and national news, campus living, and student clubs. The collection is extensive but not comprehensive, there may be some issues that were published but are not included in this collection. This collection includes issues in their original print format as well as microfilmed copies.

This collection contains issues from the student newspaper the Washington Square College Bulletin dating from 1933 to 1955. This newspaper documented student life at NYU's Washington Square campus, athletics, local and national news, campus living, and student clubs. The collection is extensive but not comprehensive, there may be some issues that were published but are not included in this collection. This collection includes issues in their original print format as well as microfilmed copies.

This collection contains issues from the student newspaper the Washington Square College Bulletin dating from 1933 to 1955. This newspaper documented student life at NYU's Washington Square campus, athletics, local and national news, campus living, and student clubs. The collection is extensive but not comprehensive, there may be some issues that were published but are not included in this collection. This collection includes issues in their original print format as well as microfilmed copies.

New York University has had many student newspapers since its founding. The University Heights campus and the Washington Square campus had separate student newspapers until 1973 when the University Heights campus was closed. The Washington Square campus held summer sessions for students, and from 1937-1947 it had its own newspaper called Summer Sessions News. The Washington Square College Bulletin, later called the Washington Square Bulletin, ran concurrent with the Heights Daily News and was succeeded by the Washington Square Journal.
Researchers must consult microfilm copies due to the fragility of the original newspapers.
